title: Mum-of-five says they desperately need larger home as son recovers from cancer
text:

A family of seven say they desperately need a bigger home to help one of them recover from cancer.

Shaffina Hassam is one of more than 6,000 people on Leicester City Council’s housing register.

Every Wednesday she is one of the thousands of people who log on to the bidding system in an attempt to find a more suitable property, Leicester Live reports.

“I’ve been trying for years to find somewhere big enough for us,” she said.

“We should have been given a four bedroom house when we moved here nine years ago. Now we need a five bed home.

(Image: BPM Media)

“We were a family of seven allocated a three bedroom house, and one of the rooms is a box room with half of it being taken up by the stairs, it’s more like two and a half bedrooms.”

Shaffina Hassam, her husband Sajid and their five children, three daughters aged 17,16 and 14 and two boys aged 12 and 10, share the house in North Evington.

Her son Mohammad Yaseen is in remission after receiving treatment for a rare cancer. It’s something that has added to Shaffina’s worry about their living situation.

“Mohammad has to have a colostomy bag because of the treatment, we only have one bathroom and we don’t have a shower in there.

“Anyone who knows about the bags will know that showers are much more hygienic and dignified for a boy in his situation.

“I have his bags, dressings, medications all out on show because there’s two of them in a bedroom barely big enough for one person.”

Mohammad’s oncologist has also written to the council advising them that he needs his own room meaning the family need a five bedroom house - something in short supply.

(Image: BPM Media)

In 2018/19 there were just five lettings of five bedroom homes, there are currently 122 families waiting for one, 27 are a higher priority than the Hassams.

Shaffina’s daughters also struggle for space.

She said: “My three girls are all in full time education still, they all share one bedroom, they have bunk beds and a pull out bed - one of them sleeps on a pull out bed.

“There are three teenage girls in a room together, they are all still studying. There’s no room for a desk in there, there’s not much room for anything.”

Shaffina said she has already been waiting years for a bigger house. The city council confirmed they applied to the housing register in 2017 and have been bidding on properties since then.

They were originally band three, a lower level of need, but were moved into band two when Mohammad became poorly.

(Image: BPM Media)

Shaffina said: “I bid each week on properties that are available. In the past I’d think about things like schools and staying in the same area but it’s got to the point now where I’ll think about moving anywhere so we don’t have to live like this any more.”

Shaffina also said she has asked for her existing home to be adapted or extended.

“If we could extend and have a downstairs bathroom and create an extra bedroom we’d be happy to stay here.

“We realise that there are lots of other people waiting for housing but it’s really difficult living like this.

“One bedroom between seven of us would be a struggle anyway but with Mohammad’s needs it’s even harder.”

A city council spokesman said: “This family registered for a move in 2017 and have been a high priority for a move since 2018 but five-bedroom homes are in desperately short supply across the city, with only five coming available across the whole of the city in the past year.

“We are going to talk to them about considering bidding for four bedroom houses rather than just five-bed, which would at least provide one extra bedroom.

“We are also in the process of buying up private properties to add to our housing stock, and are looking for five-bedroom and adapted properties, as well as bungalows, because of the growing need for them.

“We have recently established a pot of money to enable us to extend and adapt some of our homes , and are currently looking at our stock to see where this is physically possible and where there is greatest need.

"We can look at this family’s house as part of that review with a view to seeing if it is possible to extend it.”
description: The family of seven are living in a three-bedroom council house in Leicester
